title: Self-cleaning clothes and shower curtains that double up as a TV: this could be the home of the future
text:
0.14 0.00 
On Back to the Future Day, here's a preview of the cutting-edge gadgets and technological wonders in store for our homes 
Back to the Future (Other OTC: FRNWF - news ) predicted that in 2015 we'd be travelling around in flying cars or commuting by hoverboard. 
While some predictions never got off the ground, others may still become a reality. 
Take Marty McFly's self-drying jacket, for example. 
We could see the end of the weekly wash by 2030, according to Rightmove (LSE: RMV.L - news ) . 
The property website, which partnered with a group of tech experts to envisage what our homes might look like 15 years from now, says nanotech clothes are on the way. 
Self-cleaning fabrics, truly waterproof materials and personal climate control are all in development. 
Self-cleaning cotton fabrics are being developed in China with the help of nanotechnology, and the concept could prove life-changing in countries with high humidity levels. 
The secret is a nano particle coating , one already used to keep windows clear, that could lead to "self-cleaning" versions of wool and silk fabrics. 
Researchers at Harvard also said last year they had managed to modify everyday cotton and polyester fabrics to repel nearly any substance they touch: water, ice, oil, saltwater, wax, blood, and more. 
= What else is in the pipeline? = 
“Hi, sorry I can't come to the door right now, I'm out of the country". 
This could well be something you tell a visitor to your home in 15 years’ time. 
Stuart Miles, founder of technology website Pocket-lint says that every single electronics device in the home will be connected to the internet, including the doorbell. 
He thinks digital doorbells will become a must-have item in the next couple of years, as people become used to the idea of being notifed when someone is at the door, no matter where they are in the world. 
The technology will mean people can see a live video feed of who is at the door, and can give live instructions about where to leave a delivery. 
Smart doorbells are already available to buy, although they are still a relatively niche gadget used by just a fraction of households. 
= Empty cupboards that order groceries = 
Smartphones will advance to the point that we'll be able to control nearly everything in the house with them even if we're not home. 
"You'll be able to check how much milk you have in the fridge while you're at the supermarket," said Tim Danton, editor of PC Pro magazine. 
Developments in technology will also lead to houses being built with automated heating controls that sense movement and switch on the heat the minute someone opens the front door. 
Cupboards will soon be able to order groceries when stocks are running low. 
Smart security systems will also give us constant updates on who's in the house and what they're doing. 
The number of UK households which have some form of smart home system is expected to rise from 3 million this year to nearly 8 million in 2019, according to data from consultancy Strategy Analytics. 
= "Mirror, mirror on the wall..." = 
Mirrors will no longer be used just to see your reflection. A smart mirror, which is comprised of a screen with an integrated computer, will have a virtual wardrobe function so users can try different garments on a model of themselves before getting dressed. 
The magic mirror can even make polite outfit suggestions, to make sure you’re looking your best before leaving the house. 
The looking glass can even flag up traffic delays, or show the weather forecast for the day. 
Some retailers are already using smart mirrors, allowing consumers to virtually try on different outfits without needing to step into the changing room. 
= The wi-fi connected shower curtain = 
That’s right, in the future you could be washing your hair while checking the news. Using flexible display technology, your shower curtain could double up as a screen. 
This will allow consumers to access social media, listen to music or catch up on emails while in the shower. 
Combining multiple household objects into one will become more popular in future, as consumers increasingly want to make more efficient use of space. 
The coffee table of the future, for example, is likely to double as speaker and power source. 
= Smart scales that give you a daily diet plan = 
There are numerous apps that tell you how many calories you should eat a day, but in the near future this could extend to your bathroom scales. 
The scales would be integrated into a sensor pad in the floor and connected to the shower curtain screen, and could provide you with a detailed assessment of your vital statistics, letting you know many calories you should plan to consume that day. 
Other bathroom inventions include the fold-away toilet. 
Folding away neatly after use, the space-saving fold-away loo occupies much less space than toilets of the past, uses half the water and is even easier to keep clean. 
= Growing vegetables indoors and dry washing machines = 
Rising global demand for food will lead to a surge in the use of hydroponic technology, allowing households to have indoor gardens that provide fresh fruit and vegetables all year round. 
The world will need to produce at least 50pc more food by 2050 to keep the 9 billion-strong population fed. 
Pests, climate, soil and disease can all be controlled through a hydroponic system. This form of crop cultivation can also be stacked vertically to save space. 
Other household items will also become more energy-efficient. Drywashers are expected to be in widespread use in fifteen years' time to save on water and electricity. The dry washer will consist of a superconductive ball filled with liquid nitrogen that spins around a ring generating a magnetic field. 
= The advanced 3D home printer = 
Experts expect 3D printers to become as ubiquitous in the home as televisions are by 2030, and that these will radically change the face of consumerism. 
Everything from tools and electronics, to food and clothing, can be printed quickly and cheaply, using just raw material blocks and "recipes" downloaded from the internet. 
In the future we may simply download blueprints of products, which we can then print as many times as we like. 
However, this could impact a wide number of traditional industries, and potentially lead to dramatic changes in manufacturing employment.
